title: I am a stockbroker with a national firm. I need to file bankruptcy ch7.
question: Is there any special rule in the bankruptcy code for a person like myself?
question_tags: Employment law for businesses,Chapter 7 bankruptcy for businesses,Chapter 11 bankruptcy for businesses,Chapter 13 bankruptcy for businesses,Securities transactions,Liquidating business assets,Bankruptcy,Chapter 7 bankruptcy,Eligibility for filing chapter 7 bankruptcy,Chapter 11 bankruptcy,Chapter 13 bankruptcy,Debt,Bankruptcy liquidation,Bankruptcy and debt,Chapter 13 bankruptcy reorganization plan,Chapter 13 bankruptcy eligibility,Business,Employment,Discrimination in the workplace,Discrimination
answers: I agree with the answers above. You may also want to check with your bonding company to determine if it affects your bonding requirements.
There are no speacial rules in the bankruptcy code but you should check with the compliance people at your agency to make sure the filing will not affect your license or position.

The eligibility rules for filing for bankruptcy are in section 109 of the Bankruptcy Code. Those sections preclude a "stockbroker or commodity broker" from filing "Chapter 11" or "Chapter 13." It is clear the Code allows for individual stockbroker Chapter 7s.

I assume that YOU are filing not your firm? (There is a separate liquidation proceeding for stock brokerage firms under the SEC, the Securities Investment Protection Act, which I know nothing about).

The bankruptcy code also prohibits discrimination in employment or government licenses because someone has filed for bankruptcy. However, employers can find ways around that by finding other concerns about you. Having a good relationship with your employer, and letting it know before they find out otherwise would be a good idea. I have had some mortgage brokers and people with high level security clearances file. They tell me that there is actually a bigger concern about large outstanding debt (temptation) than the irresponsibility concern of a bankruptcy.

Please see a qualified bankruptcy attorney in your area. Your case needs to be done right.
